results.title: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Shelley Matulick
results.brief_description:
ACMI’s ‘Australian Perspectives’ film season frames contemporary Australian filmmaking against a backdrop of archival classics and special guest presentations.
This question and answer session with a panel of Australian film industry figures, was held on Saturday 7th September 2013 as Part 2 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’, following a screening of Nigel Buesst’s 1971 film ‘Bonjour Balwyn’.
Hosted by Rochelle Siemienowicz, the panel included Nigel Buesst, Peter Hourigan, Alan Finney and John Flaus.
The discussion highlights the key role of Melbourne, and Carlton in particular, as a centre for independent filmmaking in the 1960s and 1970s. The memories and anecdotes recounted by the panellists illustrate the vibrancy and creative energy of the Melbourne scene and the socio-economic context that allowed it to flourish.
NOTE: Part 1 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’ was an August 2013 screening of Brian Davies’ 1966 film ‘Pudding Thieves’.

results.title: Carlton + Godard = cinema [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sunrise Picture Company and Nigel Buesst
results.brief_description:
A retrospective look at the film-making movement in Carlton during the 1960s/1970s, the filmmakers and the influences that inspired and motivated them. Includes an examination of the life and work of neo-realist Giorgio Mangiamele, and the French new wave styles of Brian Davies, Peter Carmody, Antony I. Ginnane, Peter Elliot, James Clayden, Nigel Buesst, David Minter. An assembly of extracts from several of the Carlton films are juxtaposed with pieces of Godard’s early films revealing much about a fascinating period of Melbourne filmmaking.
Features Antony I. Ginnane, Geoffrey Gardner, James Clayden, Bob Garlick, Giancarlo Giusti, Graeme Cutts. Narrated by Peter Fisher.

results.title: Carl Milles: Swedish sculptor
results.creator_credit: A B Nordish Filmkopici, Radio Sweden and Doreen Denning
results.brief_description: Carl Milles was perhaps one of Sweden’s most famous sculptors. After a survey of the artist - including some unique scenes of his early works, the film takes us on a tour of the Millesgarden where a number of his works are displayed. Following his death, Millesgarden was donated to the State and is now one of Stockholm’s most frequented museums.

results.title: Caring for the future
results.creator_credit: State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Jim Hayes
results.brief_description: As demands for electricity is doubled every ten years, the State Electricity Commission of Victoria must plan at least ten years ahead. The film shows the planning that went into the Loy Yang Power plant, when more than fifty interested bodies were consulted and a great deal of careful testing and experimentation was carried out before the final plan was put into action.

results.title: Caring for our country
results.brief_description: Examines three major environmental problems with regards to land use. These are salinity, soil erosion and tree decline. The video explores the ways in which today’s farmers take responsibility for land degradation and the strategies they use to deal with these problems.

results.title: Caribbean welcome
results.brief_description: Presents the royal tour by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh of the Caribbean countries in February 1966, showing scenes in British Guiana, Trinidad and Jamaica.

results.title: Caribbean
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: Made before the Federation of the islands of the West Indies, this film shows the people, customs, export products, social problems, and scenery of the British West Indies, British Guiana, and British Honduras. Interwoven with a musical background of calypso music ritual drumming, ancient folk songs and traditional dance rhythms. (Awards: 1st prize Venice Film Festival 1951)

results.title: Cargoes
results.brief_description: The “Ionian” (a cargo ship) leaves London at the end of July 1939 to deliver cargo to the British owned ports in the Mediterranean area such as Malta and Cyprus, passing on the way many of the British naval ships as they prepare for the second World War a month later. No other credits available.

results.title: Cargo handling at the ports
results.creator_credit: Air Ministry and Great Britain. Ministry of Transport
results.brief_description: Deals with the equipment used in the handling of ships’ cargoes. Among the mechanical appliances shown are various types of crane, pick-up devices, hoppers, conveyors to transport goods from holds to railway trucks, grain elevators, floating elevators, motor tractors and trailers, electric tractors, fork-lift trucks, elevating trucks, the Ross carrier, and power-operated truck mover. Demonstrates how this equipment enables goods to be handled more quickly, so increasing the capacity of the docks.
